executive_summary: Furniture wholesalers have endured some volatility in recent years. The health of the residential and nonresidential construction sectors largely impacts new furniture sales. During the initial stages of the pandemic, wholesalers were negatively affected by rising office rental vacancies, higher unemployment and weaker corporate profit. All of these trends led to weaker demand for office furniture, the largest product segment in the industry. Although demand for home furniture grew amid near-zero interest rates and higher disposable income, these gains could not make up for losses in the commercial sector, pushing revenue down. These trends have led to revenue shrinking at an estimated CAGR of 1.3% to $61.1 billion through 2024, including a 0.8% gain that year alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Changes in macroeconomic factors impact demand for new furniture
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Disposable income has fluctuated in recent years, with sharp gains in 2020 and losses in 2022 because of heightened inflation. Since many consumers consider new furniture a discretionary purchase, lower disposable income encourages them to postpone or fully cancel buying new furniture, harming wholesalers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Office furniture sales are impacted by various macroeconomic factors
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020, significant financial difficulties pushed many businesses to stall hiring and lay off portions of their workforce as they cut down on expenses. These trends prevented the creation of new businesses, harming demand for office and commercial furniture. Businesses shifting to remote and hybrid working have harmed office furniture sales amid climbing office rental vacancies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The residential sector has endured significant volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Residential furniture is the second-largest product line for wholesalers, making revenue highly reliant on the health of the residential sector. The sector has endured significant volatility in recent years, contributing to sales fluctuations and weaker growth. Housing starts and existing home sales jumped in 2020 and 2021 due to low interest rates and high disposable income, driving demand for home furniture. However, in 2022, interest rate hikes, inflation and consumer uncertainty negatively impacted home furniture sales.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wholesaler bypass trends are becoming more common
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Large furniture manufacturers have structured their businesses to maximize profit by including distribution capabilities and company-owned retail outlets. Their growing presence has placed increasing pressure on smaller, independent wholesalers. Manufacturers selling furniture directly to downstream markets enhance competition within the industry and can offer lower prices than wholesalers, pushing many companies out of the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Stabilizing inflation and lower interest rates will enable the 30-year conventional mortgage rate to weaken, lowering the long-term cost of buying a new home and boosting demand for new home furniture from consumers. Similarly, the value of nonresidential construction will continue to expand amid recovering economic conditions. During this time, rising corporate profit and stabilizing unemployment will make the office vacancy rate fall, supporting office furniture sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continuing to Cut Out the Middleman
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Upstream and downstream industries play different roles in the supply chain, clouding the long-term outlook for traditional wholesalers. This trend of manufacturers and retailers internalizing distribution functions will continue over the coming years. As vertically integrated companies begin operating and traditional wholesalers exit, the remaining furniture wholesalers will continue to exert purchasing power and appeal to boutique retailers that cannot establish cost-effective contracts with manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: More furniture manufacturers developing distribution capabilities will continue to threaten wholesalers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: These sellers can offer lower prices, further driving price-based competition. As this trend continues, traditional wholesalers will have to operate with a smaller profit margin, which can eventually drive many to exit the industry altogether.

industry_definition: The Furniture Wholesaling industry wholesales a broad range of furniture for homes and businesses. Wholesalers purchase goods from domestic and international manufacturers and sell them to department stores, furniture specialty shops and other respective businesses.
key_trends: Larger furniture wholesalers hold a competitive advantage.
Wholesale bypass trends threaten the industry.
Office furniture wholesalers will continue to recover.
Many furniture wholesalers attract customers by offering discounts despite lower profit.
Furniture wholesalers are increasingly using advanced technology.
Furniture wholesalers must obtain a license and follow regulations.
Vertically integrated producers are driving down profit.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private businesses include offices, hotels and restaurants. These businesses buy large amounts of furniture from wholesalers that offer more favorable.
Retailers include local, regional and national furniture and department stores. These stores buy furniture from wholesalers and, more recently, directly from manufacturers to resell to consumers.
Smaller wholesalers often buy from other distributors to gain access to exclusive brands or when smaller sellers fail to meet manufacturers' order.
Government bodies include public schools, libraries and other offices. Other markets include direct sales to consumers, contract outfitters and repair shops for use in repair work.

products_and_services.product_description: Office furniture includes desks, shelves, cubicles, tables, computer chairs, filing cabinets and other office systems sold to buying businesses. The unemployment and office vacancy rates impact demand for office furniture. When these macroeconomic factors are elevated, companies have less of a need for new furniture, harming office furniture sales.

Household furniture includes upholstered furniture (couches, recliners), case goods (dressers, chests, bookshelves, cabinets) and beds and mattresses. Fluctuations impacting the residential construction sector directly impact demand for home furniture. Near-zero interest rates and high disposable income in 2020 boosted housing starts and existing home sales, pushing consumers to buy new pieces to furnish and decorate their new homes. Unfavorable macroeconomic conditions over the following years, including elevated inflation, rising interest rates and heightened consumer uncertainty, pushed many to postpone large purchases like furniture.
Commercial furniture includes furniture used for public establishments like libraries, schools and government buildings. Products used for public purposes include desks, chairs and bookshelves.
Other miscellaneous products and services of the industry.

tier_1_suppliers: Cabinet & Vanity Manufacturing in the US
Household Furniture Manufacturing in the US
Office Furniture Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Wood Product Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Office Supply Stores in the US
tier_2_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The value of residential construction measures spending by individuals and businesses on residential construction. Increases in the value of residential construction often lead to higher demand for furniture as downstream markets are spending more on furnishing residences. On the other hand, the weakening value of residential construction poses a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to many furniture wholesalers. This area's proximity to numerous retailers and its position as the most populated region in the country enhance distribution efficiency. Florida stands out within the Southeast for having the most furniture resellers. Wholesalers benefit from lower transportation costs and quicker delivery times, boosting their appeal to downstream retailers.
The West, mainly California, attracts many wholesalers because of its significant population. California hosts the most furniture wholesalers.

Furniture wholesaling businesses are heavily concentrated in the Mid-Atlantic region. The region has one of the highest per capita income in the country, providing a robust income base for wholesalers. With some of the largest ports in the country, the Mid-Atlantic is ideal for importing home furniture. New York leads in the number of furniture wholesalers in the Mid-Atlantic, benefitting from the region's wealth and strategic port locations.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Wholesalers selling to other businesses need a wholesaler's license from the US Department of Revenue. This license enables wholesalers to buy and resell goods, bolstering their credibility with manufacturers. State-specific licenses are also required. These regulations help standardize operations, ensuring trust and compliance within the furniture wholesaling industry. These licenses support growth by simplifying business transactions and fostering reliable partnerships.

Wholesalers must comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). According to the US Department of Labor, the federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour, which went into effect on July 24, 2009. States may also have minimum wage laws that provide greater employee protections. In this case, wholesalers must comply with both.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) mandates regulations on workplace safety, wages and overtime. Handling heavy furniture often requires machinery, making it essential for wholesalers to maintain an OSHA-compliant work environment. This reduces injury risks and promotes efficiency, ensuring employee safety and smooth operations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The furniture wholesale industry is mature.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.
The capital intensity level is low.
The globalization level is low but increasing.
Furniture wholesalers need a license from the US Department of Revenue to resell products and must comply with various labor regulations.
Significant entry costs deter many potential entrants due to capital investments in warehouses, inventory technology and large product purchases.
The furniture wholesale market is highly competitive with most wholesalers offering similar products, using discounts and promotions to stand out.
Furniture wholesalers depend heavily on workers and are adopting automation to lower labor reliance and boost profit.

factors_increased_barrier: The furniture wholesale industry is mature
The competition level is high and increasing.
factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.

basis_points.basis_title: Larger furniture wholesalers hold a competitive advantage
basis_points.basis_description: Market share concentration is growing as larger wholesalers acquire smaller ones, supporting their dominance in the industry.

basis_points.basis_title: Wholesale bypass trends threaten the industry
basis_points.basis_description: This cost-cutting trend is becoming increasingly popular, favoring direct-to-consumer supply chains and intensifying competition for distributors.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small companies service local downstream retailers
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is largely dominated by small, privately owned wholesalers serving smaller markets and local furniture stores.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Vertical Integration Has Increased Market Share Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Furniture manufacturers have been growing their role in the supply chain by vertically integrating from manufacturing to wholesaling to retail.
Wholesalers that carry imported furniture can offer competitive prices and efficiently compete with vertically integrated manufacturers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Are The Largest Expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wholesalers buy furniture from manufacturers and other wholesalers to resell to downstream buyers, including retailers and businesses for end use. Since wholesalers must acquire a lot of inventory, purchase costs account for wholesalers' largest expense.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Fluctuations in the prices of wood pulp and steel have contributed to rising purchase expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Supply chain disruptions, changes in downstream demand and elevated inflation push raw material suppliers to charge higher prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Large wholesalers can often negotiate favorable deals with manufacturers and offer lower prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: This can maintain a larger profit margin.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Furniture wholesalers depend heavily on workers for sales, customer service, administrative duties and logistics. The rising adoption of automation aims to lower reliance on human labor to boost profit.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changes in downstream demand drive volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry relies heavily on downstream demand from households and businesses.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Unfavorable macroeconomic conditions weaken furniture sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Lower disposable income and heightened consumer uncertainty discourage consumers from buying new home furniture.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Significant inflation and drastic interest rate hikes have contributed to revenue fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Although demand from the residential sector grew at the start of the pandemic, swelling inflation and weaker disposable income have pushed consumers to postpone large investments, such as buying new furniture.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in downstream construction markets impact demand
volatility_points.volatility_description: Changes in residential and nonresidential construction directly impact demand for new furniture pieces.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Implementing Virtual Reality is a Key Innovation
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advancements in technology have made virtual reality (VR) an accessible innovation for furniture wholesalers to adopt.
Consumer preferences are increasingly turning toward having custom, personalized furniture.

FAQs.question: How have your sales been affected by the growth of online shopping?
FAQs.answer: The emergence of online commerce stores pressures independent wholesalers by giving manufacturers a direct link to consumers.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market, major customer or other isolated revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: Diversifying sales strategies can help mitigate risk and ensure a stable revenue stream.

FAQs.question: How do you manage volatile demand that results from economic conditions or seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Companies can benefit from offering products that appeal to a variety of markets.
